recipes.title: Lemon Herb Grilled Chicken
recipes.description: This delicious lemon herb grilled chicken is perfect for those following a low FODMAP diet. The bright citrus flavors and fresh herbs make this a refreshing and satisfying dinner option.
instructions: In a large bowl or zip-top bag, combine lemon juice, olive oil, rosemary, thyme, lemon zest, garlic-infused oil, salt, and pepper.
Add chicken breasts to the marinade, ensuring they're well coated. Marinate in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes or up to 4 hours.
Preheat grill to medium-high heat (about 375-400°F or 190-200°C).
Remove chicken from marinade and discard remaining liquid.
Grill chicken for 6-7 minutes per side, or until internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
Let chicken rest for 5 minutes before serving to allow juices to redistribute.
Garnish with additional fresh herbs and lemon slices if desired.
fodmapTips: Garlic-infused oil is low FODMAP as the fructans in garlic are not oil-soluble.
Lemon juice and zest are low FODMAP and add flavor without triggering symptoms.
This recipe is naturally gluten-free and dairy-free.
Pair with low FODMAP vegetables like carrot, zucchini, or potato for a complete meal.

recipes.title: Maple Ginger Salmon
recipes.description: This maple ginger salmon is a perfect low FODMAP option with a delightful balance of sweet and savory flavors. The natural maple sweetness complements the rich salmon perfectly for an elegant yet simple dinner.
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) and line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
In a small bowl, whisk together maple syrup, tamari, grated ginger, olive oil, lime juice, salt and pepper.
Place salmon fillets on the prepared baking sheet, skin side down.
Brush the maple mixture generously over each salmon fillet.
Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until salmon flakes easily with a fork and reaches an internal temperature of 145°F (63°C).
Garnish with fresh chopped chives before serving.
fodmapTips: Pure maple syrup is low FODMAP in portions up to 2 tablespoons (40g) per serving.
Fresh ginger is low FODMAP and adds flavor without triggering symptoms.
Tamari is a great low FODMAP alternative to regular soy sauce, which may contain wheat.
Pair with low FODMAP sides like rice, quinoa, or roasted carrots for a complete meal.

recipes.title: Quinoa Breakfast Bowl
recipes.description: Start your day with this nutritious low FODMAP quinoa breakfast bowl. Packed with protein and fiber, this warm breakfast alternative to oatmeal will keep you satisfied all morning.

us: 1 cup lactose-free milk or almond milk

instructions: In a medium saucepan, combine quinoa, milk, water, and salt.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, for 12-15 minutes until liquid is absorbed.
Remove from heat and let stand, covered, for 5 minutes.
Stir in maple syrup and cinnamon.
Divide into bowls and top with strawberries, blueberries, walnuts, and pumpkin seeds.
fodmapTips: Quinoa is a low FODMAP grain that provides a good source of protein.
Use lactose-free milk or almond milk as regular milk contains lactose, a FODMAP.
Strawberries and blueberries are low FODMAP fruits in the portions specified.
Walnuts and pumpkin seeds are low FODMAP in small portions and add healthy fats.

recipes.title: Mediterranean Chicken Salad
recipes.description: This refreshing Mediterranean chicken salad is perfect for a light lunch that won't trigger IBS symptoms. Packed with protein and fresh vegetables, it's as nutritious as it is delicious.

us: ¼ cup red bell pepper, diced
¼ cup fresh basil leaves, torn

instructions: In a large bowl, combine lettuce, cucumber, tomatoes, bell pepper, olives, and basil.
In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, Dijon mustard, oregano, salt, and pepper.
Add the cooked chicken to the salad bowl.
Drizzle the dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
Sprinkle with feta cheese before serving.
fodmapTips: Cherry tomatoes are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (75g).
Cucumber is low FODMAP with the skin on in servings up to ½ cup (75g).
Red bell peppers are low FODMAP in servings up to ¼ cup (38g).
Feta cheese is typically low in lactose, but use a lactose-free version if you're very sensitive.

recipes.title: Peanut Butter Energy Balls
recipes.description: These no-bake peanut butter energy balls make the perfect low FODMAP snack. They're great for on-the-go energy boosts without triggering digestive symptoms.

us: ¼ cup dark chocolate chips (low FODMAP)

instructions: In a large bowl, mix together peanut butter, maple syrup, and vanilla extract until well combined.
Add in the rolled oats, ground flaxseed, chia seeds, and salt. Mix until thoroughly combined.
Fold in the chocolate chips.
Cover and refrigerate the mixture for 30 minutes to make it easier to handle.
Using a tablespoon, scoop the mixture and roll into 12 balls with your hands.
Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to one week.
fodmapTips: Natural peanut butter is low FODMAP in servings up to 2 tablespoons (32g).
Oats are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (52g) per sitting.
Dark chocolate is low FODMAP in servings up to 30g (check that it doesn't contain high FODMAP ingredients).
Chia seeds and flaxseed are low FODMAP and provide healthy omega-3 fatty acids.

recipes.title: Spaghetti Squash Pasta
recipes.description: This low FODMAP spaghetti squash pasta is a delicious alternative to traditional pasta dishes. The light vegetable base pairs perfectly with a simple herb-infused tomato sauce.

us: ½ cup fresh basil leaves, chopped

instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Cut the spaghetti squash in half lengthwise and scoop out the seeds.
Brush the cut sides with 1 tablespoon olive oil and season with salt and pepper.
Place the squash halves cut-side down on the prepared baking sheet.
Bake for 35-45 minutes, until the flesh is tender and can be easily scraped with a fork.
While the squash is baking, heat garlic-infused oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add diced tomatoes, dried oregano, thyme, salt, and pepper.
Simmer for 15-20 minutes, until the sauce thickens slightly.
Stir in balsamic vinegar and half of the fresh basil. Remove from heat.
When squash is done, let it cool slightly, then use a fork to scrape the flesh into spaghetti-like strands.
Toss the spaghetti squash with the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil.
Serve topped with tomato sauce, remaining fresh basil, and toasted pine nuts if using.
fodmapTips: Spaghetti squash is a low FODMAP alternative to regular pasta.
Garlic-infused oil provides the flavor without the FODMAPs, as the fructans in garlic are not oil-soluble.
Canned tomatoes are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (92g) per sitting.
This recipe can be made with gluten-free pasta instead of spaghetti squash if preferred.

recipes.title: Blueberry Lemon Muffins
recipes.description: These gluten-free blueberry lemon muffins are perfect for a low FODMAP breakfast or snack. The bright citrus flavor complements the sweet blueberries for a delicious morning treat.

us: ½ cup lactose-free milk or almond milk

instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Line a 12-cup muffin tin with paper liners.
In a large bowl, whisk together gluten-free flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.
In a separate bowl, beat eggs and then add lactose-free milk, oil, vanilla extract, lemon juice, and lemon zest.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir just until combined. Do not overmix.
Gently fold in the blueberries.
Divide batter evenly among the muffin cups, filling each about ¾ full.
If using, sprinkle coarse sugar on top of each muffin.
Bake for 22-25 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Allow muffins to cool in the pan for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely.
fodmapTips: Blueberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 20 berries (28g) per sitting.
Use a certified gluten-free all-purpose flour blend that doesn't contain high FODMAP ingredients like chickpea flour.
Lactose-free milk or almond milk are both suitable low FODMAP alternatives to regular milk.
Lemon juice and zest add flavor without adding FODMAPs.

recipes.title: Teriyaki Tofu Stir-Fry
recipes.description: This flavorful teriyaki tofu stir-fry is a plant-based low FODMAP dinner option. The homemade teriyaki sauce is carefully crafted to be stomach-friendly while still delivering that classic sweet and savory taste.

eu: 15g green parts of spring onions, chopped
us: 14 oz firm tofu, pressed and cubed
¼ cup green parts of spring onions, chopped

instructions: Press tofu for at least 15 minutes to remove excess moisture, then cut into 1-inch cubes.
In a small bowl, whisk together tamari, maple syrup, rice vinegar, grated ginger, garlic-infused oil, cornstarch, and water to make the teriyaki sauce.
Heat 1 tablespoon sesame oil in a large wok or skillet over medium-high heat.
Add tofu cubes and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side until golden brown. Remove from pan and set aside.
Add remaining 1 tablespoon sesame oil to the pan.
Add carrots and stir-fry for 2 minutes, then add red bell pepper and continue cooking for 2 more minutes.
Add bok choy and bean sprouts, and stir-fry for another 2 minutes until vegetables are tender-crisp.
Return tofu to the pan and pour the teriyaki sauce over everything.
Cook for 2-3 minutes until the sauce thickens and coats everything evenly.
Stir in the green parts of spring onions and remove from heat.
Garnish with sesame seeds and serve over rice if desired.
fodmapTips: Use only the green parts of spring onions, as the white parts are high in FODMAPs.
Garlic-infused oil provides flavor without the FODMAPs present in fresh garlic.
Bean sprouts, bok choy, carrots, and red bell peppers are all low FODMAP vegetables in the portions specified.
Tamari is a gluten-free alternative to regular soy sauce, which may contain wheat.

recipes.title: Banana Oat Pancakes
recipes.description: These fluffy banana oat pancakes are a delicious low FODMAP breakfast option. Made with just the right amount of ripe banana to stay within low FODMAP guidelines, they're the perfect weekend treat.

eu: 30g unsalted butter or coconut oil, melted (plus more for cooking)
us: 1 cup lactose-free milk or almond milk
2 tablespoons unsalted butter or coconut oil, melted (plus more for cooking)

instructions: In a food processor or blender, process the rolled oats until they become a coarse flour.
In a large bowl, whisk together the ground oats, gluten-free flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt.
In a separate bowl, beat the eggs, then add lactose-free milk, mashed banana, maple syrup, vanilla extract, and melted butter or coconut oil.
Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and stir until just combined. Let the batter rest for 5 minutes.
Heat a non-stick pan or griddle over medium heat and lightly grease with butter or oil.
For each pancake, pour about ¼ cup of batter onto the pan. Cook until bubbles form on the surface, about 2-3 minutes.
Flip the pancake and cook for another 1-2 minutes until golden brown and cooked through.
Serve warm with fresh strawberries and a drizzle of maple syrup if desired.
fodmapTips: Unripe bananas are high in FODMAPs, but ripe bananas (with brown spots) are low FODMAP in portions up to 33g per sitting.
This recipe uses one banana divided into 4 servings, keeping each serving within low FODMAP guidelines.
Lactose-free milk or almond milk are both suitable low FODMAP alternatives to regular milk.
Strawberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 5 medium or 65g per sitting.

recipes.title: Chocolate Chia Pudding
recipes.description: This creamy chocolate chia pudding is a delicious low FODMAP dessert that requires minimal effort. Just mix, chill, and enjoy this nutritious treat that's full of fiber and healthy fats.

us: 2 cups almond milk or lactose-free milk

instructions: In a medium bowl, whisk together almond milk, cocoa powder, maple syrup, vanilla extract, and salt until well combined.
Add chia seeds and whisk thoroughly to prevent clumping.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight, stirring once after about 30 minutes to break up any clumps.
When ready to serve, give the pudding a good stir. If it's too thick, add a splash more almond milk.
Divide into serving bowls and top with fresh raspberries and dark chocolate shavings if desired.
fodmapTips: Chia seeds are low FODMAP and provide excellent fiber content, which can help regulate digestion.
Almond milk is low FODMAP in servings up to 1 cup (250ml) per sitting.
Cocoa powder is low FODMAP in servings up to 2-3 heaped teaspoons (8g) per sitting.
Raspberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 30 berries (60g) per sitting.

recipes.title: Spinach and Feta Frittata
recipes.description: This easy spinach and feta frittata is a protein-packed low FODMAP breakfast option. Perfect for meal prep, it can be enjoyed hot or cold and stores well in the refrigerator for quick weekday breakfasts.

us: ¾ cup feta cheese, crumbled (lactose-free if needed)

instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a large bowl, whisk together eggs, lactose-free milk, dried oregano, salt, and pepper.
Heat olive oil in a 10-inch oven-safe skillet over medium heat.
Add spinach and cook until wilted, about 2-3 minutes.
Pour the egg mixture over the spinach.
Sprinkle the crumbled feta cheese and halved cherry tomatoes evenly over the top.
Cook on the stovetop for 5 minutes until the edges start to set.
Transfer the skillet to the preheated oven and bake for 12-15 minutes, until the eggs are set and the top is lightly golden.
Let cool for 5 minutes before slicing into wedges.
Garnish with fresh chives before serving.
fodmapTips: Spinach is low FODMAP in servings up to 2 cups (56g) per sitting.
Feta cheese is typically low in lactose, but use a lactose-free version if you're very sensitive.
Cherry tomatoes are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (75g).
This frittata can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days and reheated as needed.

recipes.title: Quinoa Tabbouleh Salad
recipes.description: This refreshing quinoa tabbouleh salad is a low FODMAP twist on the classic Middle Eastern dish. Using quinoa instead of bulgur wheat makes it gluten-free while still maintaining the fresh, herby flavors of traditional tabbouleh.

eu: 30g green parts of spring onions, chopped
us: ½ cup fresh mint leaves, finely chopped
⅓ cup green parts of spring onions, chopped

instructions: In a medium saucepan, combine rinsed quinoa, water, and ¼ teaspoon salt. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 15 minutes, or until water is absorbed and quinoa is fluffy.
Transfer quinoa to a large bowl and allow to cool to room temperature. Fluff with a fork occasionally as it cools.
Once cooled, add cucumber, cherry tomatoes, parsley, mint, and green parts of spring onions to the quinoa.
In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, remaining ½ teaspoon salt, and black pepper.
Pour the dressing over the salad and toss gently to combine.
For best flavor, refrigerate for at least 30 minutes before serving to allow the flavors to meld.
fodmapTips: Use only the green parts of spring onions as the white parts are high in FODMAPs.
Cucumber is low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (75g).
Cherry tomatoes are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (75g).
Quinoa is a low FODMAP grain that provides a good source of protein and fiber.

recipes.title: Herb-Crusted Salmon with Roasted Vegetables
recipes.description: This herb-crusted salmon with roasted vegetables is an elegant yet simple low FODMAP dinner option. The herb crust adds wonderful flavor to the salmon while the colorful roasted vegetables make for a complete and satisfying meal.

eu: 150g red bell pepper, cut into 2cm pieces
us: 2 cups carrots, cut into ¾-inch pieces
2 cups parsnips, cut into ¾-inch pieces
1½ cups red bell pepper, cut into ¾-inch pieces

instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
In a bowl, toss carrots, parsnips, and red bell pepper with 1 tablespoon olive oil, salt, and pepper.
Spread vegetables on the prepared baking sheet and roast for 15 minutes.
Meanwhile, in a small bowl, mix together dill, parsley, thyme, remaining olive oil, lemon juice, Dijon mustard, gluten-free breadcrumbs, salt, and pepper.
Remove baking sheet from oven and push vegetables to one side.
Place salmon fillets on the baking sheet and spread the herb mixture evenly over the top of each fillet.
Return to oven and bake for 10-12 minutes more, until salmon is cooked through and vegetables are tender.
Serve salmon with roasted vegetables and lemon wedges on the side.
fodmapTips: Carrots, parsnips, and red bell peppers are all low FODMAP vegetables.
Ensure the gluten-free breadcrumbs don't contain high FODMAP ingredients like onion or garlic powder.
Dijon mustard is low FODMAP in servings up to 1 teaspoon (5g) per sitting.
This meal provides a good balance of protein, healthy fats, and low FODMAP vegetables.

recipes.title: Berry Coconut Crumble
recipes.description: This warm berry coconut crumble is a comforting low FODMAP dessert option. The sweet-tart berries pair perfectly with the crunchy coconut topping for a dessert that's both satisfying and gentle on sensitive stomachs.

eu: Dairy-free vanilla ice cream for serving (optional)
us: ⅓ cup coconut sugar or brown sugar
Dairy-free vanilla ice cream for serving (optional)

instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Lightly grease an 8×8-inch (20×20 cm) baking dish.
In a large bowl, gently mix strawberries, blueberries, granulated sugar, lemon juice, and cornstarch until well combined.
Pour the berry mixture into the prepared baking dish, spreading it evenly.
In another bowl, mix together rolled oats, gluten-free flour, coconut sugar, shredded coconut, cinnamon, and salt.
Add melted coconut oil and maple syrup to the dry ingredients. Stir until the mixture is crumbly and well combined.
Sprinkle the crumble topping evenly over the berry mixture.
Bake for 30-35 minutes, until the topping is golden brown and the filling is bubbling around the edges.
Let cool for 10-15 minutes before serving.
Serve warm with dairy-free vanilla ice cream if desired.
fodmapTips: Strawberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 5 medium or 65g per sitting.
Blueberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 20 berries or 28g per sitting.
The serving size of this dessert keeps the berry amounts within low FODMAP guidelines.
Coconut products are low FODMAP in moderate amounts and add great flavor without triggering symptoms.

recipes.title: Roasted Pumpkin Seed Trail Mix
recipes.description: This savory roasted pumpkin seed trail mix makes for a perfect low FODMAP snack on the go. It's crunchy, satisfying, and full of nutrients without any added sugar, making it ideal for those watching their sugar intake.

eu: 25g dried cranberries (look for varieties without added sugar)
us: 1 cup rice puffs or puffed quinoa (unsweetened)
¼ cup dried cranberries (look for varieties without added sugar)

instructions: Preheat oven to 325°F (165°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
In a large bowl, combine pumpkin seeds, sunflower seeds, smoked paprika, cumin, salt, and black pepper.
Drizzle with olive oil and toss until all seeds are evenly coated with oil and spices.
Spread the seed mixture in a single layer on the prepared baking sheet.
Roast in the preheated oven for 12-15 minutes, stirring halfway through, until the seeds are golden and fragrant.
Remove from oven and let cool completely on the baking sheet.
Once cooled, transfer the roasted seeds to a large bowl. Add the rice puffs and dried cranberries and mix well.
Store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 weeks.
fodmapTips: Pumpkin seeds and sunflower seeds are low FODMAP in the portions specified.
Look for dried cranberries that don't contain high FODMAP sweeteners like high-fructose corn syrup or honey.
Rice puffs and puffed quinoa are good low FODMAP alternatives to granola or cereal in trail mixes.
This trail mix is a great portable snack option for when you're away from home and need a low FODMAP option.

recipes.title: Polenta with Roasted Vegetables
recipes.description: This creamy polenta topped with colorful roasted vegetables is a satisfying vegetarian low FODMAP dinner option. The combination of comforting polenta with flavorful roasted vegetables creates a balanced and nutritious meal.

eu: 50g parmesan cheese, grated (omit for vegan option)
30g butter or olive oil (use olive oil for vegan option)
200g red bell pepper, cut into chunks
us: 4 cups water or vegetable stock (low FODMAP)
½ cup parmesan cheese, grated (omit for vegan option)
2 tablespoons butter or olive oil (use olive oil for vegan option)
1 cup red bell pepper, cut into chunks

instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper.
In a large bowl, toss zucchini, bell pepper, eggplant, and cherry tomatoes with olive oil, rosemary, thyme, garlic-infused oil, ½ teaspoon salt, and black pepper.
Spread vegetables on the prepared baking sheet in a single layer.
Roast for 25-30 minutes, stirring once halfway through, until vegetables are tender and lightly caramelized.
Meanwhile, in a large saucepan, bring water or stock to a boil with remaining ½ teaspoon salt.
Slowly whisk in the polenta, stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
Reduce heat to low and simmer, stirring frequently, for 15-20 minutes until polenta is thick and creamy.
Remove from heat and stir in parmesan cheese and butter or olive oil until melted and well combined.
Divide polenta among four bowls, top with roasted vegetables, and garnish with fresh basil leaves.
fodmapTips: Polenta is a naturally gluten-free and low FODMAP grain option.
If using stock, ensure it's low FODMAP without onion or garlic.
Zucchini is low FODMAP in servings up to ⅓ cup (65g) per sitting.
Eggplant is low FODMAP in servings up to 1 cup (75g) per sitting.
Parmesan cheese is naturally low in lactose and suitable for most people with lactose intolerance.

recipes.title: Overnight Oats with Berries
recipes.description: These simple overnight oats with berries make a perfect low FODMAP breakfast that you can prepare ahead of time. With no added sugar, they're a healthy way to start your day that's also gentle on your digestive system.

us: ½ cup lactose-free milk or almond milk

instructions: In a mason jar or container with a lid, combine oats, milk, chia seeds, cinnamon, vanilla extract, and salt. Stir well.
Seal the container and refrigerate overnight, or for at least 6 hours.
In the morning, stir the oat mixture. If it's too thick, add a splash more milk.
Top with sliced strawberries, blueberries, and a drizzle of maple syrup if desired.
Enjoy cold or warm it up in the microwave for 30-60 seconds if preferred.
fodmapTips: Oats are low FODMAP in servings up to ½ cup (52g) per sitting.
Strawberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 5 medium or 65g per sitting.
Blueberries are low FODMAP in servings up to 20 berries or 28g per sitting.
If needed, this recipe can be made without the maple syrup for a completely sugar-free option.
